paragraphs.context: The geography of Malaysia includes both the physical and the human geography of Malaysia, a Southeast Asian country made up of two major landmasses separated by water—Peninsular Malaysia to the west and East Malaysia to the east—and numerous smaller islands that surround those landmasses. Peninsular Malaysia is on the southernmost part of the Malay Peninsula, south of Thailand, north of Singapore and east of the Indonesian island of Sumatra; East Malaysia comprises most of the northern part of Borneo, and shares land borders with Brunei to the north and Indonesian Borneo to the south.

paragraphs.context: Malaysia is a federation of thirteen states and three federal territories, which form the primary administrative divisions of the country. Eleven states and two territories are part of Peninsular Malaysia, while two states and one territory make up East Malaysia. Nine of the Peninsular states have monarchies, with the other four having appointed governors. State governments are led by chief ministers, who are appointed by the monarch or governor, provided they have the support of a majority in the state legislative assembly. The federal territories are governed directly by the national government. Malaysia was formed through the union of various territories ruled by the United Kingdom. The federal system was created to maintain the status of the Malay sultans, who were the rulers of British protectorates in the Malay Peninsula. The Federation of Malaya was created in 1948, uniting these protectorates with two directly ruled British colonies. Malaya became independent in 1957. In 1963,

answers.text: to maintain the status of the Malay sultans

paragraphs.context: Kuala Lumpur (KL), officially the Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, is the capital city and a federal territory of Malaysia. It is the largest city in the country, covering an area of 243 km2 (94 sq mi) with a census population of 2,075,600 as of 2024. Greater Kuala Lumpur, also known as the Klang Valley, is an urban agglomeration of 8.8 million people as of 2024. It is among the fastest growing metropolitan regions in Southeast Asia, both in population and economic development. The city serves as the cultural, financial, tourism, political and economic centre of Malaysia. It is also home to the Malaysian parliament (consisting of the Dewan Rakyat and the Dewan Negara) and the Istana Negara, the official residence of the monarch (Yang di-Pertuan Agong). Kuala Lumpur was first developed around 1857 as a town serving the tin mines of the region, and important figures such as Yap Ah Loy and Frank Swettenham were instrumental in the early development of the city during the late 19th centu

answers.text: Yap Ah Loy and Frank Swettenham

paragraphs.context: Sarawak is a state of Malaysia. It is the largest among the 13 states, with an area almost equal to that of Peninsular Malaysia. Sarawak is located in East Malaysia in northwest Borneo, and is bordered by the Malaysian state of Sabah to the northeast, Kalimantan to the south, and Brunei in the north. The state capital, Kuching, is the largest city in Sarawak, the economic centre of the state, and the seat of the Sarawak state government. Other cities and towns in Sarawak include Miri, Sibu, and Bintulu. As of the 2020 Malaysia census, the population of Sarawak was 2.453 million. Sarawak has an equatorial climate with tropical rainforests and abundant animal and plant species. It has several prominent cave systems at Gunung Mulu National Park. Rajang River is the longest river in Malaysia; Bakun Dam, one of the largest dams in Southeast Asia, is located on one of its tributaries, the Balui River. Mount Murud is the highest point in Sarawak.

answers.text: on one of its tributaries, the Balui River

paragraphs.context: Langkawi, officially known as Langkawi, the Jewel of Kedah, is a duty-free island and an archipelago of 99 islands (plus five small islands visible only at low tide in the Strait of Malacca) located some 30 km off the coast of northwestern Malaysia and a few kilometres south of Ko Tarutao, adjacent to the Thai border. Politically, it is an administrative district of Kedah, with Kuah as its largest town. Langkawi was developed as a tourist destination in the 1980s, and Pantai Cenang is the island's most popular beach and tourist area.

paragraphs.context: Mount Kinabalu is the highest mountain in Malaysia and Borneo. With a height of 4,095 metres, it is the third-highest peak of an island on Earth, the 28th highest peak in Southeast Asia, and 20th most prominent mountain in the world. The mountain is located in Ranau district, West Coast Division of Sabah, Malaysia. It is protected as Kinabalu Park, a World Heritage Site. In 1997, a re-survey using satellite technology was conducted. It established Mount Kinabalu had a summit known as Low's Peak height of 4,095 m above sea level, some 6 m less than the previously published figure of 4,101 m. The mountain and its surroundings have exceptional biodiversity, with 5,000 to 6,000 species of plants, 326 species of birds, and over 100 mammalian species identified. Among this rich collection of wildlife are famous species such as the Rafflesia plants and orangutans.

qas.question: Where is Mount Kinabalu located?

answers.text: Ranau district, West Coast Division of Sabah, Malaysia

paragraphs.context: The prime minister of Malaysia is the head of government of Malaysia. The prime minister directs the executive branch of the federal government. The Yang di-Pertuan Agong appoints the prime minister who is a member of Parliament who, in his opinion, is most likely to command the confidence of a majority of MPs. The prime minister is usually the leader of the party winning the most seats in a general election. After the formation of Malaysia on 16 September 1963, Tunku Abdul Rahman, the chief minister of the Federation of Malaya, became the first prime minister of Malaysia.

paragraphs.context: The King of Malaysia, officially Yang di-Pertuan Agong, is the constitutional monarch and ceremonial head of state of Malaysia. The office was established in 1957, when the Federation of Malaya gained independence from the United Kingdom. The Yang di-Pertuan Agong is elected by the Conference of Rulers, comprising the nine rulers of the Malay states, with the office rotated between them. The 17th and current Yang di-Pertuan Agong is Ibrahim Iskandar of Johor. He was elected on 26 October 2023 at a special meeting of the Conference of Rulers; he took the oath of office and was sworn in at the Istana Negara on 31 January 2024. The queen consort is known as the Raja Permaisuri Agong, currently Raja Zarith Sofiah.

paragraphs.context: The Federal Constitution of Malaysia is the supreme law of Malaysia and contains a total of 183 articles. It came into force in 1957 as the Constitution of the Federation of Malaya and was amended in 1963 to form the Constitution of Malaysia. It is a written legal document influenced by two previous documents, the Federation of Malaya Agreement 1948 and the Independence Constitution of 1957. The Federation was initially called the Federation of Malaya and adopted its present name, Malaysia, when Sabah, Sarawak and Singapore became part of the Federation. The Constitution establishes the Federation as a constitutional monarchy, having the Yang di-Pertuan Agong as the Head of State with largely ceremonial roles. It provides for the establishment and organisation of three main branches of government: the bicameral legislative branch called the Parliament.

paragraphs.context: The Parliament of Malaysia is the national legislature of Malaysia, based on the Westminster system. The bicameral parliament consists of the Dewan Rakyat (House of Representatives) and the Dewan Negara (Senate). The Yang di-Pertuan Agong (King), as the head of state, is the third component of Parliament. The Parliament assembles in the Malaysian Houses of Parliament, located in the national capital city of Kuala Lumpur. The term Member of Parliament usually refers to a member of the Dewan Rakyat, the lower house of the Parliament. The term Senator usually refers to a member of the Dewan Negara, the upper house of the Parliament.

paragraphs.context: Barisan Nasional is a political coalition of Malaysia that was founded in 1974 as a coalition of centre-right and right-wing political parties to succeed the Alliance Party. It is the third largest political coalition with 30 seats in the Dewan Rakyat after Pakatan Harapan with 82 seats and Perikatan Nasional with 74 seats. The coalition consists of the United Malays National Organisation, Malaysian Chinese Association, Malaysian Indian Congress, and United Sabah People's Party. The coalition employed the same inter-communal governing model of its predecessor but on a wider scale. It ruled Malaysian politics for over thirty years after it was founded. Taken together with its predecessor, it governed from 1957 to 2018, making it the longest ruling coalition.

paragraphs.context: Pakatan Harapan is a Malaysian political coalition consisting of centre-left political parties formed in 2015 to succeed the Pakatan Rakyat coalition. It has led a grand coalition government since November 2022, and previously led a single-coalition government from May 2018 to February 2020. It is currently the largest coalition in the Dewan Rakyat with 81 seats and is part of the state governments of seven out of 13 states, including Penang, Selangor, Negeri Sembilan, Perak, Pahang, Malacca, and Sabah. It also provides confidence and supply in Johor. The coalition includes the Democratic Action Party (DAP), People's Justice Party (PKR), National Trust Party (AMANAH), and United Progressive Kinabalu Organisation (UPKO). Pakatan Harapan defeated Barisan Nasional during the 2018 Malaysian general election, ending its 60-year-long reign.

paragraphs.context: The 1Malaysia Development Berhad scandal, or 1MDB scandal, is a corruption, bribery and money laundering conspiracy involving the Malaysian sovereign wealth fund 1MDB. The fund was systematically embezzled, with assets diverted globally. Although it began in 2009 in Malaysia, the scandal's scope became international, involving political, banking, and entertainment sectors, and prompted criminal investigations in several countries. The United States Department of Justice described it in 2016 as the largest kleptocracy case to date. A 2015 document leak revealed that Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak had transferred over RM 2.67 billion, roughly US$700 million, from 1MDB into his personal accounts.

answers.text: the largest kleptocracy case to date

paragraphs.context: Mahathir bin Mohamad was born on 10 July 1925. He is a Malaysian politician, author, and physician who served as the fourth and seventh prime minister of Malaysia from 1981 to 2003 and again from 2018 to 2020. He was the country's longest-serving prime minister, with a total of 24 years. His political career has spanned over 75 years, from protests in the 1940s to forming the Gerakan Tanah Air coalition in 2022. During his premiership, Mahathir was given the title Father of Modernisation for his role in transforming Malaysia's economy and infrastructure. Nearly 100 years old, he is currently the oldest living former Malaysian prime minister. Born and raised in Alor Setar, Kedah, Mahathir excelled in school and became a physician. He became active in UMNO and entered parliament in 1964.

paragraphs.context: Anwar bin Ibrahim was born on 10 August 1947. He is a Malaysian politician and the 10th prime minister of Malaysia since 2022. He has been president of the People's Justice Party since 2018 and chairman of Pakatan Harapan since 2020. He is the Member of Parliament for Tambun and also serves as finance minister. A University of Malaya graduate, Anwar held leadership roles in student and Islamic organisations before joining UMNO. He was appointed deputy prime minister in 1993 and finance minister in 1991. He was active during the 1997 Asian financial crisis. In 1998, he was removed from his positions by then-prime minister Mahathir Mohamad.

paragraphs.context: Malaysia is a modern concept formed in the late 20th century, but its history traces back to ancient times through Malaya and Borneo. Notable events include the formation of the federation, Singapore's separation, racial riots, Mahathir Mohamad's industrialisation policies, and political changes in recent decades. The region shows evidence of human occupation dating back 1.83 million years and of modern humans about 40,000 years ago. The present-day Malaysian population has roots in various prehistoric and historic migration waves. Hinduism and Buddhism were dominant from the 7th to 13th centuries during the Srivijaya Empire.

paragraphs.context: The Malacca Sultanate was a Malay sultanate based in the modern-day state of Malacca, Malaysia. Historical accounts suggest it was founded around the year 1400 by Parameswara, also known as Iskandar Shah. At its height in the 15th century, its capital became one of the most important transshipment ports of its era, extending its influence across the Malay Peninsula, the Riau Islands, and part of eastern Sumatra. Malacca became a center for Islamic learning and development of the Malay language, literature, and arts. Classical Malay became the lingua franca of Maritime Southeast Asia, and Jawi script was widely used.

paragraphs.context: The 13 May incident was a period of violent racial conflict that erupted in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on 13 May 1969, following that year's general election. The clashes primarily involved the Malay and Chinese communities and were triggered by political and ethnic tensions after opposition parties such as the Democratic Action Party and Gerakan made substantial electoral gains, challenging the ruling Alliance Party's dominance. Processions by opposition supporters were perceived by segments of the Malay community as provocative, worsening grievances and igniting the violence. In response, the king declared a state of emergency, suspended parliament, and handed civilian administration to the National Operations Council under Deputy Prime Minister Tun Abdul Razak. Official sources cited 196 fatalities, though some scholars argue the real number was closer to 600. Thousands were injured or displaced.

paragraphs.context: The Malayan Emergency, also known as the Anti-British National Liberation War, was a guerrilla war from 1948 to 1960 fought between communist pro-independence fighters of the Malayan National Liberation Army and the forces of the Federation of Malaya and the British Commonwealth. The communists aimed to establish a communist state and end British colonial rule, while the British and Malayan governments fought to suppress the rebellion and maintain control. The term 'Emergency' was chosen by British authorities so that insurance policies would still be valid, as they typically excluded coverage during times of war. The war began on 17 June 1948, after attacks on British plantations led to the declaration of a state of emergency. Chin Peng led the Malayan Communist Party.

answers.text: so that insurance policies would still be valid

paragraphs.context: Independence Day, also known as Hari Merdeka, is the day the Federation of Malaya gained independence from the British Empire. It commemorates the Malayan Declaration of Independence on 31 August 1957 and is defined in article 160 of the Constitution of Malaysia. Ceremonies are held nationwide. There is debate about whether Malaysia’s true national day should be Malaysia Day on 16 September instead, since Malaysia was formed in 1963 when North Borneo, Sarawak, Singapore, and Malaya merged. Some, particularly in East Malaysia, argue that celebrating 31 August 1957 is inaccurate because Malaysia did not exist until six years later.

Signed in London, the agreement took effect on 16 September 1963. Singapore was later expelled and became independent on 9 August 1965.

paragraphs.context: The Communist insurgency in Malaysia, also known as the Second Malayan Emergency, was an armed conflict from 1968 to 1989 between the Malayan Communist Party (MCP) and Malaysian federal security forces. After the Malayan Emergency ended in 1960, the MCP’s armed wing, the Malayan National Liberation Army, retreated to the Malaysian-Thailand border to regroup. Hostilities resumed with an ambush at Kroh–Betong on 17 June 1968. The conflict coincided with ethnic tensions in Malaysia and the Vietnam War. The MCP received limited support from the People's Republic of China.

paragraphs.context: Chinese Malaysians are citizens of Malaysia of Chinese ethnicity. They are the second-largest ethnic group in the country, making up 23.2% of citizens as of 2020. Globally, they represent the second-largest overseas Chinese community after Thai Chinese. Many are descendants of Southern Chinese immigrants who arrived between the 19th and mid-20th centuries. Most trace their origins to Fujian and Guangdong provinces. They speak various Chinese dialects, such as Hokkien, Teochew, Cantonese, Hakka, and Hainanese, and play an important role in Malaysia’s economy.

answers.text: Hokkien, Teochew, Cantonese, Hakka, and Hainanese

paragraphs.context: Indo-Malaysians are Malaysians of South Asian ancestry. Most are descendants of those who migrated from India to British Malaya between the mid-19th and mid-20th centuries. Most Malaysian Indians are ethnic Tamils; smaller groups include the Malayalees, Telugus, and Punjabis. Malaysian Indians form the fifth-largest community of Overseas Indians in the world. In Malaysia, they represent the third-largest ethnic group, constituting 7% of the population, after the Bumiputera and the Chinese. They are often referred to as Indians in English and Orang India in Malay. The community has a notable class divide, with both elite professionals and a significant low-income population. In 1999, Malaysian Indians made up 15.5% of Malaysia's professionals, although this has since declined, and a large portion now lives in poverty.

qas.question: Which ethnic group makes up the majority of Malaysian Indians?

paragraphs.context: Bumiputera is a term used in Malaysia to describe Malays, the Orang Asli of Peninsular Malaysia, various indigenous peoples of East Malaysia, and the Peranakans. The word comes from Sanskrit and means 'son of the land' or 'son of the soil.' In Indonesia, the term 'Pribumi' has a similar meaning. In the 1970s, the Malaysian government introduced policies that favored bumiputera, such as affirmative action in education and public employment, to uplift the economically disadvantaged community. These measures were implemented to reduce ethnic tensions following the 13 May Incident in 1969 and to support the Malay majority with special rights.

qas.question: What does the term 'Bumiputera' literally mean?

answers.text: Malays, the Orang Asli, indigenous peoples of East Malaysia, and the Peranakans

qas.question: Why did the Malaysian government implement Bumiputera policies in the 1970s?

answers.text: to uplift the economically disadvantaged community and reduce ethnic tensions

paragraphs.context: The Orang Asli are an indigenous minority in Malaysia and are considered the oldest inhabitants of Peninsular Malaysia. As of 2017, they made up 0.7% of the population of Peninsular Malaysia. Despite being a small group, their special status is protected by law. Orang Asli communities are usually located in mountainous or forested areas. Though commonly grouped together, they consist of many distinct tribes and cultures, each with its own language and customs. What unites them is their difference from Malaysia's three major ethnic groups: Malays, Chinese, and Indians.

paragraphs.context: Kadazandusun are the largest ethnic group in Sabah, Malaysia, an amalgamation of the closely related Kadazan and Dusun peoples. The term Kadazandusun refers to both communities. They are also known as Mamasok Sabah, meaning indigenous people of Sabah. Kadazandusun tradition holds that they descend from Nunuk Ragang. Kadazandusun is recognized as an indigenous nation of Borneo with heritage documented by UNESCO since 2004. As part of the bumiputera in Malaysia, they have rights related to land, rivers, education, and their own customary laws.

paragraphs.context: The Malaysian diaspora refers to Malaysians and their descendants residing abroad. The population is estimated at nearly two million and includes both early and recent emigrants. The largest Malaysian communities abroad are found in Singapore, Australia, Brunei, and the United Kingdom. Emigration has various causes, including institutional racism. Malaysia does not officially track emigration, so numbers rely on destination country data. As of 2019, the estimated population of the Malaysian diaspora was 1,730,152 according to the United Nations.

paragraphs.context: Islam is the state religion of Malaysia, as defined by Article 3 of the Constitution. Other religions may be practiced by non-Malay citizens. Other religions can be practiced legally, but religious freedom is limited. As of 2024, about 22.4 million Malaysians (65% of the population) were Muslim. Islamic holidays like Eid al-Fitr, Eid al-Adha, and Mawlid are celebrated alongside holidays such as Christmas, Chinese New Year, and Deepavali.

paragraphs.context: Thaipusam is a Tamil Hindu festival celebrated on the first full moon day of the Tamil month of Thai, coinciding with the Pusam star. It commemorates the victory of the Hindu god Murugan over the demon Surapadman. Murugan is believed to have used a divine spear, or vel, given by his mother Parvati. The festival includes Kavadi Aattam, a ceremonial act of sacrifice where devotees carry physical burdens to repay spiritual debts. Worshipers carry pots of milk as offerings and may pierce their skin, tongue, or cheeks with vel skewers. Preparation includes remaining clean, praying regularly, following a vegetarian diet, fasting, and staying celibate. Thaipusam is observed by Tamils in India, Sri Lanka, Malaysia, Singapore, and Indonesia.

qas.question: What does Thaipusam commemorate?

answers.text: the victory of the Hindu god Murugan over the demon Surapadman

paragraphs.context: Eid al-Fitr, also known as the Festival of Breaking the Fast, is one of the two major Islamic holidays. It is celebrated on the first day of Shawwal, the tenth month of the Islamic calendar, marking the end of Ramadan. Muslims worldwide observe it, though it is known by different names in various cultures. The celebration includes a special salah consisting of two rakats, performed in congregation, with additional Takbirs. In the Hanafi school, there are three Takbirs in the first and three before bowing in the second rakat. Other Sunni traditions usually include twelve Takbirs.

qas.question: When is Eid al-Fitr celebrated?

answers.text: on the first day of Shawwal

paragraphs.context: Chinese New Year, or the Spring Festival, marks the beginning of the new year on the traditional lunisolar Chinese calendar. The celebration begins on Chinese New Year's Eve and ends with the Lantern Festival on the 15th day. The first day of Chinese New Year falls on the new moon between 21 January and 20 February. It is associated with myths and traditions, including honoring deities and ancestors. Regional customs vary widely across China.

Malay is also spoken by ethnic Malays in Indonesia and southern Thailand. In total, it is spoken by about 60 million people. Malay is a pluricentric macrolanguage, meaning it consists of multiple related dialects that are mutually intelligible and considered distinct by their speakers. paragraphs.context: Malaysian English, formally called Malaysian Standard English, is a variety of English used in Malaysia. It is closely related to British English. While Malaysian English refers broadly to all forms of English used in the country, some consider it separate from the informal style known as Manglish.

paragraphs.context: Malaysia's indigenous languages belong to the Mon-Khmer and Malayo-Polynesian families. Malay is the official language and the native language of the majority ethnic Malays. Major ethnic groups include Bumiputera (such as Malays and Orang Asli), Malaysian Chinese, and Malaysian Indians, with many smaller groups, each having its own language. In East Malaysia, large native languages include Iban, Dusunic, and Kadazan. English is widely spoken in urban areas, is a compulsory school subject, and is used in most private institutions. In Sabah and Sarawak, English may be used officially under the National Language Act.

qas.question: Which families do Malaysia's indigenous languages belong to?

paragraphs.context: Tamil Malaysians are people of full or partial Tamil descent who were born in or immigrated to Malaysia from Tamil Nadu, India and north-east Sri Lanka. The majority of 1.8–2 million people, or 80% of the Malaysian Indian population, are of Indian Tamil ethnic background. Most Tamil migration to Malaysia began during the British Raj, when Britain facilitated labor migration to plantations through the Kangani system. Some Tamil communities were present even before British colonialism.

qas.question: Where did most Tamil Malaysians originate from?

answers.text: Tamil Nadu and north-east Sri Lanka

paragraphs.context: Education in Malaysia is overseen by the Ministry of Education. While education is a federal responsibility, each state and federal territory has its own Education Department. The main law governing education is the Education Act 1996. Education typically receives about 14% of the national budget, the largest allocation. The system is divided into five stages: preschool, primary, secondary, post-secondary, and tertiary. Education is further divided into national and private sectors. Malaysians may receive free education through the national system, or attend private or international schools. Primary education is compulsory by law.

qas.question: Which act governs the education system in Malaysia?
How many stages are there in Malaysia's education system?
Is primary education in Malaysia compulsory?

paragraphs.context: The Malaysian University English Test (MUET) is a test of English proficiency used mainly for university admissions in Malaysia. It is administered by the Malaysian Examinations Council and was introduced in 1999. MUET is accepted in Malaysia and Singapore, and also recognized in countries like the United Kingdom, United States, and Hong Kong. MUET is required for admission to all public universities in Malaysia, and it is also used by public servants for qualification and promotion. Since 2012, the test has been conducted three times per year: March, July, and November.

qas.question: Who administers the Malaysian University English Test (MUET)?
Since when has MUET been conducted three times a year?
What is MUET mainly used for in Malaysia?

paragraphs.context: Taman Negara is a national park in Peninsular Malaysia. It was established in 1938 and 1939 as the King George V National Park after Theodore Hubback lobbied the sultans of Pahang, Terengganu, and Kelantan to create a protected area spanning the three states. After independence, it was renamed Taman Negara, meaning 'national park' in Malay. The park spans 4,343 square kilometers and is one of the world’s oldest rainforests, dating back over 130 million years. It includes Mount Tahan, the highest point in Peninsular Malaysia at 2,187 meters. The park is rich in biodiversity and home to endangered species like the Malayan tiger and Asian elephant. It also overlaps with traditional lands of several Orang Asli groups, including the Batek people.

qas.question: What does 'Taman Negara' mean in Malay?
Which mountain is located within Taman Negara?
Which indigenous group traditionally lives within Taman Negara?

paragraphs.context: Borneo is the third-largest island in the world, covering 748,168 square kilometers, and had a population of over 23 million in 2020. Located at the center of Maritime Southeast Asia, it is one of the Greater Sunda Islands and is crossed by the equator. Politically, Borneo is divided among three countries: Brunei occupies 1% of the island in the north, Indonesia covers about 73%, and Malaysia occupies roughly 26% through its states Sabah and Sarawak. Labuan is a Malaysian federal territory located just off the coast of Borneo.

qas.question: Which countries share the island of Borneo?

paragraphs.context: The Cameron Highlands is a district in Pahang, Malaysia, covering an area of 712.18 square kilometers. It borders Kelantan to the north and Perak to the west. Located at the northwestern tip of Pahang, it is about 90 kilometers east of Ipoh and 200 kilometers north of Kuala Lumpur. It is the state's smallest municipality. Surveyed by William Cameron in 1885, it consists of three subdistricts: Ringlet, Tanah Rata, and Ulu Telom. There are eight settlements including Brinchang, Bertam Valley, Kea Farm, and Kampung Raja. These communities are located between 800 and 1,603 meters above sea level.

qas.question: Which state is Cameron Highlands located in?
Who surveyed the Cameron Highlands?
What is the elevation range of settlements in Cameron Highlands?

answers.text: between 800 and 1,603 meters above sea level

paragraphs.context: This is a list of the bird and mammal species and subspecies described as endangered by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. It includes species found not only in the U.S. and its territories, but also those native to other parts of the world. It does not include fish, amphibians, reptiles, plants, or invertebrates. Endangered species are listed under U.S. Code of Federal Regulations Title 50 Part 17. The status codes are E for endangered and T for threatened. Some species may also be listed due to similar appearance and are marked as E(S/A) or T(S/A). Threatened species are those likely to become endangered in the foreseeable future. The primary goals of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's program are to identify, protect, and restore endangered and threatened species.

qas.question: Which agency maintains the endangered species list referenced in the article?

answers.text: United States Fish and Wildlife Service

qas.question: What does the status code E(S/A) indicate?

answers.text: similarity of appearance to an endangered species

qas.question: What are the goals of the U.S. endangered species program?

answers.text: identify, protect, and restore endangered and threatened species

paragraphs.context: Malaysia is a country in Southeast Asia, composed of 13 states and three federal territories. It is divided into Peninsular Malaysia and East Malaysia by the South China Sea. Peninsular Malaysia shares land borders with Thailand and maritime borders with Singapore, Vietnam, and Indonesia. East Malaysia, located on Borneo, shares borders with Brunei and Indonesia, and maritime borders with the Philippines and Vietnam. Kuala Lumpur is the national capital and largest city, while Putrajaya is the federal administrative capital. With over 34 million people, Malaysia ranks as the 42nd most populous country in the world.

paragraphs.context: The Kinabatangan River is located in the Sandakan Division of eastern Sabah, Malaysia. It is Malaysia’s second longest river, stretching 560 kilometers from the mountains of southwest Sabah to the Sulu Sea. The river passes through regions rich in biodiversity, including limestone caves at Gomantong Hill, dipterocarp forests, riverine forests, freshwater swamps, oxbow lakes, and mangrove swamps near the coast.

Malaysia is located in Southeast Asia and is divided into two main regions by the South China Sea: Peninsular Malaysia to the west and East Malaysia to the east. Peninsular Malaysia lies south of Thailand, north of Singapore, and east of Sumatra. paragraphs.context: Palm oil production is vital for Malaysia's economy, making it the world's second-largest producer after Indonesia. The Malaysian Palm Oil Board (MPOB) promotes and develops the sector. The industry generates about 90 million tonnes of biomass annually, including empty fruit bunches, palm trunks, and fronds, as well as palm oil mill effluent (POME). In 2010, the government pledged to limit expansion by preserving at least half of the country's land as forest. Malaysia has committed to capping palm oil cultivation at 6.5 million hectares and maintaining over 50% forest cover.

qas.question: Which organization is responsible for overseeing Malaysia's palm oil sector?
What environmental measure did Malaysia pledge in 2010 regarding palm oil expansion?

answers.text: preserving at least half of the country's land as forest

paragraphs.context: Tourism in Malaysia is a major industry and contributor to the Malaysian economy. Malaysia was once ranked 9th in the world for tourist arrivals. In 2017, the Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Report ranked Malaysia 26 out of 141 countries using its Travel & Tourism Competitiveness Index (TTCI) which measures the various components and policies of a country that are in place to allow for the sustainable development of its travel and tourism sectors. In an effort to diversify Malaysia's economy and reduce its dependency on exports, the government pushed to increase tourism in Malaysia. This led tourism to become Malaysia's second largest source of foreign exchange income. In 2022, tourism contributed 14% to Malaysia's overall GDP. The government agency in charge of promoting tourism in Malaysia is Tourism Malaysia or the Malaysia Tourism Promotion Board (MTPB). On 20 May 1987, the Ministry of Culture, Arts and Tourism (MOCAT) was established and TDC moved to this new ministry.

qas.question: What percentage of Malaysia's GDP did tourism contribute in 2022?
What is the name of the agency responsible for promoting tourism in Malaysia?

answers.text: Tourism Malaysia or the Malaysia Tourism Promotion Board (MTPB)

qas.question: Why did the Malaysian government promote tourism?

answers.text: to diversify Malaysia's economy and reduce its dependency on exports

paragraphs.context: The automotive industry in Malaysia consists of 27 vehicle producers and over 640 component manufacturers. The Malaysian automotive industry is the third largest in Southeast Asia, and the 23rd largest in the world, with an annual production output of over 500,000 vehicles. The automotive industry contributes 4% or RM 40 billion to Malaysia's GDP, and employs a workforce of over 700,000 throughout a nationwide ecosystem. The automotive industry in Malaysia traces its origins back to the British colonial era. Ford Malaya became the first automobile assembly plant in Southeast Asia upon its establishment in Singapore in 1926. The automotive industry in post-independence Malaysia was established in 1967 to spur national industrialisation. The government offered initiatives to encourage the local assembly of vehicles and manufacturing of automobile components. In 1983, the government became directly involved in the automotive industry through the establishment of national car company Proton.

qas.question: What percentage of Malaysia's GDP is contributed by the automotive industry?

What national car company was established by the Malaysian government in 1983?

paragraphs.context: Technology Park Malaysia (TPM) is a science park located in Bukit Jalil, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia for research and development of knowledge-based industries. It spans 750 acres and contains 13 buildings, each with specific functions. TPM provides support services, technology and R&D capabilities to promote science, technology, and innovation. Its offerings include rental of incubator space, land lease for tech-based companies, and business incubation programs. TPM also offers business mentoring, marketing and financial consulting, forums, workshops, and commercialization support such as advisory and project management services.

qas.question: Where is Technology Park Malaysia located?
What kind of companies does TPM lease land to?
What types of services does TPM provide?

answers.text: business incubation, mentoring, consulting, and commercialization support

paragraphs.context: Agriculture in Malaysia makes up twelve percent of the nation's GDP. Sixteen percent of the population of Malaysia is employed through some sort of agriculture. Large-scale plantations were established by the British. These plantations opened opportunity for new crops such as rubber (1876), palm oil (1917), and cocoa (1950). A number of crops are grown for domestic purpose such as bananas, coconuts, durian, pineapples, rice and rambutan.

paragraphs.context: The economy of Malaysia is an emerging and developing, upper-middle income, highly industrialised, mixed economy. It ranks the 36th largest in the world in terms of nominal GDP, but when measured by purchasing power parity, its GDP ranks 30th. Malaysia is forecasted to have a nominal GDP of nearly half a trillion US dollars by the end of 2024. The labour productivity of Malaysian workers ranks 62nd globally. Malaysia outperforms similar income group peers in business competitiveness and innovation. Global Competitiveness Report 2024 ranks it 34th most competitive, while Global Innovation Index 2024 ranks it 33rd most innovative. Malaysia is the 35th most trade-intensive economy globally with trade making up 132% of its GDP.

qas.question: What is Malaysia's global rank in nominal GDP?

paragraphs.context: Wawasan 2020 or Vision 2020 is a Malaysian ideal introduced by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad during the Sixth Malaysia Plan in 1991. It aimed for Malaysia to become a self-sufficient industrialised nation by 2020. The vision included goals of economic growth, social well-being, world-class education, political stability, and psychological balance. Mahathir projected 7% annual economic growth from 1990 to 2020, making the economy eight times larger than its 1990 GDP of RM115 billion—equivalent to RM920 billion in 2020. Vision 2020 was implemented through three development phases: National Development Policy (1991–2000), National Vision Policy (2001–2010), and the New Economic Model (2011–2020).

qas.question: Who introduced Malaysia's Vision 2020?
What annual growth rate was projected to achieve Vision 2020?
What are the three development policy phases under Vision 2020?

answers.text: National Development Policy, National Vision Policy, and New Economic Model

paragraphs.context: The cinema of Malaysia consists of feature films produced in Malaysia, shot in the languages Malay, Mandarin, Cantonese, Tamil, various indigenous languages, and English. Malaysia produces about 60 feature films and 300–400 television dramas and serials per year, in addition to the in-house productions of individual television stations. The country also holds its own annual national level film awards, known as the Malaysia Film Festival. There are about 150 cinemas and cineplexes in Malaysia, which show both domestic and foreign produced films. Foreign film producers are welcome to shoot on location in Malaysia and to undertake film co-production ventures, which provide local artists and those with technical roles the opportunity to gain exposure and experience. Currently internationally famous Malaysian actors include Academy Award winner Michelle Yeoh and Henry Golding.

paragraphs.context: Malaysian television broadcasting was introduced on 28 December 1963. Colour television was introduced on 28 December 1978. Full-time colour transmissions were officially inaugurated on New Year's Day 1982. There are currently 16 national free-to-air terrestrial television channels in Malaysia and 3 national pay subscription television operators in Malaysia.

paragraphs.context: All-Asian Satellite Television and Radio Operator, doing business as Astro, is a Malaysian pay satellite television, streaming television and IPTV provider. Astro is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Astro Malaysia Holdings Berhad and is operated by MEASAT Broadcast Network Systems Sdn. Bhd. It operates from the All Asia Broadcast Centre in Kuala Lumpur and MEASAT in Cyberjaya. Astro forms part of the media duopoly in Malaysia alongside Media Prima. It launched Astro B.yond (HD) in 2009, Astro IPTV in 2011, Astro Ultra (UHD) in 2019, and Astro Ulti (FHD) in 2021. Astro also operated in Indonesia from 2006 to 2008 under Astro Nusantara.

paragraphs.context: Music of Malaysia is the generic term for music created across various genres in the country. It reflects the diverse cultural groups within multiethnic Malaysian society: Malay, Javanese, Chinese, Indian, Dayak, Kadazan-Dusun, Bajau, Orang Asli, Melanau, Kristang and others. Malaysian music may be categorized as classical, folk, syncretic, popular, and contemporary art music. Classical and folk music emerged during the pre-colonial era, including genres like Nobat, Mak Yong, Mak Inang, Dikir Barat, Ulek Mayang, and Menora. Syncretic music developed after the Portuguese period in the 17th century and blends local traditions with Arabian, Persian, Indian, Chinese, and Western influences.

qas.question: What are the five main categories of Malaysian music?

answers.text: classical, folk, syncretic, popular, and contemporary art music

qas.question: Which cultural groups contribute to the diversity of Malaysian music?

answers.text: Malay, Javanese, Chinese, Indian, Dayak, Kadazan-Dusun, Bajau, Orang Asli, Melanau, Kristang and others

qas.question: What is syncretic music in Malaysia influenced by?

answers.text: Arabian, Persian, Indian, Chinese, and Western influences

paragraphs.context: Malays are an Austronesian ethnoreligious group native to eastern Sumatra, the Malay Peninsula, and coastal Borneo, including smaller nearby islands. These areas span parts of Malaysia, Indonesia, southern Thailand, Singapore, and Brunei. There is great cultural and artistic diversity among Malay subgroups, shaped by centuries of migration and assimilation in Maritime Southeast Asia. Malay traditions include music, language, and dance. Historically, the Malays descended from Malayic-speaking Austronesians and Austroasiatic tribes who established early maritime kingdoms such as Brunei, Kedah, Langkasuka, Gangga Negara, and Chi Tu.

qas.question: Where are Malays traditionally native to?

answers.text: eastern Sumatra, the Malay Peninsula, and coastal Borneo

paragraphs.context: Batik Air Malaysia, formerly Malindo Air, is a full-service airline based in Malaysia and a subsidiary of Indonesia's Lion Air Group. Headquartered in Petaling Jaya, Selangor, the airline operates flights across Asia-Pacific, South Asia, and the Middle East. Established in 2013, it initially offered a hybrid model combining low fares with premium services. In 2022, the airline rebranded to align with Batik Air Indonesia, improving operational synergy. The airline’s hub is Kuala Lumpur International Airport and its fleet includes Boeing 737 MAX and Airbus A330 aircraft.

paragraphs.context: Wayang kulit is a traditional form of shadow puppetry originally found in the cultures of Java and Bali in Indonesia. In a wayang kulit performance, the puppet figures are rear-projected on a linen screen with a coconut oil or electric light. The dalang, or shadow artist, manipulates carved leather figures between the lamp and the screen. The narratives typically revolve around good versus evil. Wayang kulit is one of many types of wayang theatre, including wayang beber, wayang klitik, wayang golek, wayang topeng, and wayang wong. It uniquely blends ritual, storytelling, and entertainment. On November 7, 2003, UNESCO designated wayang kulit and other wayang forms as a Masterpiece of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity.

qas.question: What is the primary theme of wayang kulit narratives?
Who manipulates the puppets in a wayang kulit performance?

paragraphs.context: The Bisaya are an indigenous group from the northwest coast of East Malaysia and Brunei on the island of Borneo. In Sabah, they live around Beaufort and Kuala Penyu, and are part of the Kadazan-Dusun group. In Sarawak, they are grouped under the Orang Ulu designation. Their language is highly similar to the Tatana Dusun language. Today, most Bisaya in Sabah are Muslims, while those in Sarawak are primarily Christians. In Brunei, they are known as Dusun, Jati Dusun, and Bisaya.

qas.question: Where are the Bisaya people mainly located?

answers.text: northwest coast of East Malaysia and Brunei

qas.question: Which group is the Bisaya associated with in Sabah?

answers.text: Muslims in Sabah and Christians in Sarawak

paragraphs.context: Malaysian literature refers to literary works produced in the Malay Peninsula before 1963 and in Malaysia after that. It is written in Malay, English, Chinese, and Tamil, and reflects different aspects of Malaysian life. Oral literature was the earliest form, including myths, legends, folk tales, romances, epics, poetry, and proverbs. It thrived among the Malays and still survives among indigenous people such as the Orang Asli and ethnic groups in Sarawak and Sabah.

paragraphs.context: Nasi lemak is a dish originating in Malay cuisine that consists of rice cooked in coconut milk and pandan leaf. It is commonly found in Malaysia, where it is considered the national dish. It is also a native dish in neighbouring areas with significant ethnic Malay populations, such as Singapore and Southern Thailand. In Indonesia, it is found in parts of Sumatra, especially in Riau, Riau Islands, and Medan. It is considered an essential part of a typical Malay-style breakfast. Nasi lemak is also found in the Bangsamoro region of Mindanao, as well as Christmas Island and the Cocos Islands.

paragraphs.context: A lakh is a unit in the Indian numbering system equal to one hundred thousand (100,000). In the Indian 2, 2, 3 digit grouping, it is written as 1,00,000. paragraphs.context: Teh tarik is a popular hot milk tea beverage found in restaurants, outdoor stalls, mamaks and kopitiams in Southeast Asia, especially in Malaysia, Brunei, Indonesia, Singapore, and Thailand. The name comes from the act of pouring the tea back and forth between containers to cool it and give it a frothy top. It is made with a strong brew of black tea and condensed milk. paragraphs.context: Char kway teow is a stir-fried rice noodle dish originating from Maritime Southeast Asia, specifically southern Chinese communities. The term 'char' means stir-fried, and 'kway teow' refers to flat rice noodles. It is typically cooked over high heat with ingredients like garlic, soy sauce, chili paste, prawns, cockles, Chinese chives, sausage, and bean sprouts. Other variations may include fishcake and belachan. Originally developed for overseas Chinese laborers, the dish is now widely popular in Malaysia and Singapore.

paragraphs.context: Universiti Teknikal Malaysia Melaka (UTeM) is a public university located in Durian Tunggal, Malacca. paragraphs.context: Halal is an Arabic word meaning 'permissible'. It is often associated with Islamic dietary laws, especially meat prepared according to Islamic guidelines. Beyond food, halal governs ethics in business, finance, and daily life, emphasizing fairness, justice, and ethical treatment of animals. It originates from the Quran and the Sunnah. Halal is contrasted with haram, meaning 'forbidden'. Islamic jurisprudence outlines what is halal or haram, and scholars interpret these rules to ensure compliance. A more complex classification known as 'the five decisions' expands upon this binary.

qas.question: What does the Arabic word 'halal' mean?
What is the opposite of halal according to the Quran?
Besides food, what areas of life does halal influence?

paragraphs.context: The history of Asia is the collective history of several coastal regions including East Asia, South Asia, Southeast Asia, and the Middle East, linked by the Eurasian steppe. These coastal regions were home to some of the earliest civilizations and religions, often developed around fertile river valleys. Fertile soil supported the growth of root crops. Ancient civilizations in Mesopotamia, India, and China shared similarities and likely exchanged technology such as mathematics and the wheel. Writing systems developed independently in these regions. Cities, states, and empires emerged in these areas. Meanwhile, the steppe region was long inhabited by mounted nomads.

qas.question: Which regions in Asia developed early civilizations around fertile river valleys?

answers.text: Mesopotamia, ancient India, and ancient China

qas.question: What geographic feature connected the distinct coastal regions of Asia?
What technology or ideas were likely exchanged between early Asian civilizations?

paragraphs.context: Geography of Asia involves the classification of the continent into different regions. Asia comprises 58 countries and territories, making it the largest and most diverse continent in terms of geography, culture, and population.

Which aspects make Asia the most diverse continent?

paragraphs.context: Asian cuisine includes diverse cooking styles from Central, East, North, South, Southeast, and West Asia. Each culture has distinct customs, techniques, and ingredients. Often referred to as Eastern cuisine, it reflects culinary beliefs and cooking traditions passed through generations. Asian cuisine is known for its rich use of spices and ingredients like rice, garlic, ginger, sesame seeds, soy, and tofu. Umami, a savory flavor, is a key component achieved through fermented foods or meat extracts. Common cooking methods include stir frying, steaming, and deep frying.

qas.question: What are common ingredients in East and Southeast Asian cuisines?

answers.text: rice, garlic, ginger, sesame seeds, soy, and tofu

qas.question: What term is often used to describe the savory taste in Asian cooking?
Which cooking techniques are common in Asian cuisine?

answers.text: stir frying, steaming, and deep frying

paragraphs.context: Asia is the largest and most populous continent and the birthplace of many religions including Buddhism, Christianity, Confucianism, Hinduism, Islam, Jainism, Judaism, Shinto, Sikhism, Taoism, Korean shamanism, and Zoroastrianism. All major religious traditions are practiced in the region and new forms are constantly emerging. Asia is noted for its diversity of culture. Hinduism and Islam are the largest religion in Asia with approximately 1.2–1.3 billion adherents each.

qas.question: Which two religions are the largest in Asia by number of adherents?
Name three religions that originated in Asia.
What characteristic of Asia contributes to the diversity of its religions?

paragraphs.context: The economy of Asia comprises about 4.7 billion people (60% of the world population) living in 50 different nations. Asia is the fastest growing economic region, as well as the largest continental economy by both GDP Nominal and PPP in the world. It is the site of major modern economic booms. Wealth in Asia differs widely due to its vast cultural, environmental, and governmental variety. The largest economies by GDP (PPP) include China, India, Japan, Indonesia, and Turkey, while by nominal GDP they include China, India, Japan, South Korea, and Singapore. Wealth is mainly concentrated in East Asia, South Asia, and Southeast Asia.

qas.question: What percentage of the world population lives in Asia?
Which countries are the largest Asian economies by purchasing power parity?

answers.text: China, India, Japan, Indonesia, and Turkey

qas.question: Why does wealth vary significantly across Asian countries?

answers.text: due to its vast cultural, environmental, and governmental variety

paragraphs.context: The Four Asian Tigers refer to Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea, and Taiwan—developed Asian economies that industrialized rapidly from the 1950s to 1990s and achieved growth rates over 7% annually. By the 21st century, they evolved into high-income economies with competitive advantages. Hong Kong and Singapore became financial hubs, while South Korea and Taiwan led in electronics and manufacturing. They are viewed as models for developing countries, including the Tiger Cub Economies in Southeast Asia. A 1993 World Bank report credited neoliberal policies and export-led growth for their success.

qas.question: Which four economies are known as the Four Asian Tigers?

answers.text: Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea, and Taiwan

qas.question: What common economic strategy did the Asian Tigers use for rapid growth?
Which sectors did Hong Kong and Singapore specialize in?

paragraphs.context: The Asia–Pacific (APAC), also known as Indo-Pacific, is the region adjoining the western Pacific Ocean and forms part of the Old World. Boundaries vary, but Australasia, East Asia, and Southeast Asia are usually included. In broader contexts, regions like Central Asia, North Asia, Pacific Islands, South Asia, West Asia (including the Arabian Peninsula and the Levant), and even Pacific-adjoining nations in the Americas may be included. For example, APEC includes Canada, Chile, Mexico, Peru, and the United States. The term grew popular in commerce, finance, and politics since the late 1980s. Despite economic diversity, many nations in the region are emerging markets with significant growth.

qas.question: Which regions are most commonly included in the Asia-Pacific definition?

answers.text: Australasia, East Asia, and Southeast Asia

qas.question: What organization includes Pacific-adjoining countries like Canada and Chile?
Why did the term 'Asia-Pacific' gain popularity in the late 1980s?

paragraphs.context: East Asia is a region that includes China, Japan, Mongolia, North Korea, South Korea, and Taiwan, along with Hong Kong and Macau. Its economies—such as those of China, Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan—are among the most prosperous. East Asia borders North Asia, Southeast Asia, South Asia, and Central Asia. The Pacific Ocean lies to its east. Chinese civilization is considered one of the earliest cradles of civilization. Other ancient cultures include Japanese, Korean, and Mongolian. Some civilizations like Tibet and Ryukyu were absorbed into neighboring powers.

qas.question: Which four economies in East Asia are among the most prosperous?

answers.text: China, Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan

paragraphs.context: The Middle East is a geopolitical region that includes the Arabian Peninsula, the Levant, Turkey, Egypt, Iran, and Iraq. The term gained use in the early 20th century, replacing 'Near East' and contrasting with 'Far East.' It has been criticized for being Eurocentric. The region overlaps closely with West Asia but excludes the South Caucasus. It includes all of Egypt and all of Turkey. Most Middle Eastern countries belong to the Arab world. The most populous are Egypt, Turkey, and Iran. Saudi Arabia is the largest by area.

paragraphs.context: The Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) is a Eurasian political, economic, international security and defence organization of ten member states. It was established in 2001 by China, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Russia, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. India and Pakistan joined in 2017, Iran in 2023, and Belarus in 2024. Several countries participate as observers or dialogue partners. The SCO is the world's largest regional organization by geographic scope and population, covering about 24% of the world’s area and 42% of its population. As of 2024, its nominal GDP is around 23% and about 36% based on PPP. It evolved from the Shanghai Five group formed in 1996.

qas.question: When was the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation founded?

What was the SCO's predecessor organization?

paragraphs.context: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is a regional bank that promotes social and economic development in Asia. It is headquartered in Metro Manila, Philippines, and has 31 field offices worldwide. Established on 19 December 1966, ADB began with 31 members and expanded to 69 by 2019. Its membership includes UNESCAP countries and non-regional developed countries. Modeled after the World Bank, ADB uses a weighted voting system tied to capital contributions. It issues annual reports and offers the ADB-Japan Scholarship Program (ADB-JSP), supporting about 300 students annually across 10 countries in the region.

qas.question: Where is the Asian Development Bank headquartered?
How many members did the ADB have by 2019?
What is the ADB's voting system based on?

paragraphs.context: The Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), also called One Belt One Road or the New Silk Road, is a global development strategy launched by China in 2013. It aims to invest in over 150 countries and organizations. BRI includes six land-based development corridors and a Maritime Silk Road focused on port development. The initiative blends road, rail, energy, and digital infrastructure. It is both a geopolitical and geoeconomic project. China's President Xi Jinping first announced it as the Silk Road Economic Belt during a visit to Kazakhstan in 2013. The 'belt' refers to overland trade routes across Central Asia, while the 'road' refers to Indo-Pacific sea routes.

qas.question: When was the Belt and Road Initiative first announced?
What infrastructure components are part of the BRI?

answers.text: road, rail, energy, and digital infrastructure

qas.question: What does the 'road' in Belt and Road refer to?

paragraphs.context: The Trans-Asian Railway (TAR) is a project to create an integrated freight railway network across Europe and Asia. It is a project of the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (UNESCAP). Initiated in the 1950s, the goal was to establish an 8,750-mile (14,080 km) continuous rail link between Singapore and Istanbul, with possible extensions to Europe and Africa. At the time, shipping and air travel were less developed, and TAR aimed to reduce shipping time and cost between Europe and Asia. Political and economic challenges delayed progress through the 1960s to 1980s. After the Cold War ended, prospects improved as international relations normalized. The project is also seen as a response to growing Eurasian trade.

qas.question: What is the goal of the Trans-Asian Railway project?

answers.text: to create an integrated freight railway network across Europe and Asia

qas.question: Which organization oversees the Trans-Asian Railway?

answers.text: United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific

qas.question: Which two cities are at either end of the planned TAR route?

paragraphs.context: Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is a country at the eastern edge of mainland Southeast Asia. It has an area of about 331,000 square kilometers and a population of over 100 million, making it the world's fifteenth most populous country. It shares land borders with China, Laos, and Cambodia, and maritime borders with Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia, and Malaysia. The capital is Hanoi and the largest city is Ho Chi Minh City. Vietnam was inhabited during the Paleolithic age and saw states emerge in the Red River Delta in the first millennium BC. It was later annexed by the Han dynasty and remained under Chinese rule from 111 BC to 938 AD.

paragraphs.context: Bangladeshis are the citizens and nationals of Bangladesh, a South Asian country centered on the historical Bengal region. Bangladeshi citizenship was formed in 1971 when East Pakistan became the independent republic of Bangladesh. It is the world's eighth most populous country. The majority of its people are Bengalis, an Indo-Aryan ethnic group. Most live in the Bengal delta, a fertile region with a long history of urban and agrarian civilizations. The Chittagong Hill Tracts and Sylhet Division are home to various tribal minorities. Bengali Muslims are the largest ethnoreligious group, numbering 150.36 million or about 91% of the population in 2022.

answers.text: Chittagong Hill Tracts and Sylhet Division

paragraphs.context: Pakistan, officially the Islamic Republic of Pakistan, is a country in South Asia. It is the fifth-most populous country, with a population of over 241.5 million, having the second-largest Muslim population as of 2023. Islamabad is the nation's capital, while Karachi is its largest city and financial centre. Pakistan is the 33rd-largest country by area. Bounded by the Arabian Sea on the south, the Gulf of Oman on the southwest, and the Sir Creek on the southeast, it shares land borders with India to the east; Afghanistan to the west; Iran to the southwest; and China to the northeast. It shares a maritime border with Oman and is separated from Tajikistan by Afghanistan's Wakhan Corridor. Pakistan is home to ancient cultures, including the 8,500-year-old Neolithic site of Mehrgarh, the Indus Valley Civilization, and the ancient Gandhara civilization.

paragraphs.context: Sri Lanka, officially the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka, also known historically as Ceylon, is an island country in South Asia. It lies in the Indian Ocean, southwest of the Bay of Bengal, separated from India by the Gulf of Mannar and the Palk Strait. It shares maritime borders with the Maldives, India, Andaman and Nicobar Islands, and Myanmar. Sri Jayawardenepura Kotte is the legislative capital, while Colombo is the administrative and judicial capital. Kandy is the second-largest city and the capital of the last native kingdom. Sinhala is the most spoken language with about 17 million speakers, and Tamil is spoken by around five million people.

paragraphs.context: Kazakhstan is a landlocked country primarily in Central Asia with a small portion in Eastern Europe. It borders Russia, China, Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, and Turkmenistan, and has a coastline along the Caspian Sea. Astana is the capital, while Almaty is the largest city and cultural hub. Kazakhstan is the world's ninth-largest country and the largest landlocked nation. Hilly plateaus and plains make up half its land, with lowlands and mountainous regions comprising the rest. It has a population of 20 million and one of the lowest population densities in the world. Ethnic Kazakhs are the majority, with ethnic Russians as a significant minority. Kazakhstan is officially secular and a Muslim-majority country.

paragraphs.context: Uzbekistan is a doubly landlocked country in Central Asia bordered by Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Afghanistan, and Turkmenistan. It is one of only two doubly landlocked countries in the world. With over 37.6 million people, Uzbekistan is the most populous country in Central Asia. Uzbek is the official language; Russian and Tajik are also spoken. Islam is the predominant religion, mainly Sunni. Historically, the region was inhabited by Eastern Iranian nomads called Scythians, who established kingdoms in Khwarazm, Bactria, and Sogdiana in the 8th–6th centuries BC.

paragraphs.context: Saudi Arabia is a country in West Asia occupying most of the Arabian Peninsula. It borders the Red Sea, Persian Gulf, and eight countries including Jordan, Iraq, Kuwait, Bahrain, Qatar, UAE, Oman, and Yemen. It is the fifth-largest country in Asia and the twelfth-largest in the world. The capital is Riyadh, with other major cities like Jeddah, Mecca, and Medina. It is the only country with coastlines on both the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf. Much of the land is arid desert, steppe, and mountains. With almost 32.2 million people, it is the fourth most populous Arab country.

paragraphs.context: Iran, officially the Islamic Republic of Iran, also known as Persia, is a country in West Asia. It borders Iraq, Turkey, Azerbaijan, Armenia, Russia, Turkmenistan, Afghanistan, and Pakistan, with coastlines on the Gulf of Oman and the Persian Gulf. Iran is the 17th-largest country by both land area and population. It is the sixth-largest in Asia and one of the most mountainous countries globally. Tehran is the capital, largest city, and financial center. Iran has ancient roots as a cradle of civilization. The Elamites inhabited the region in 3200 BCE. The Medes unified Iran politically in the 7th century BCE, and the Achaemenid Empire was founded by Cyrus the Great in the 6th century BCE.

paragraphs.context: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) is a country in West Asia at the eastern end of the Arabian Peninsula. It is a federal semi-constitutional monarchy composed of seven emirates, with Abu Dhabi as its capital. It borders Oman, Saudi Arabia, and has maritime borders with Qatar, Iran, and Oman. As of 2024, the population is over 10 million, but only 11% are Emiratis. Dubai is the largest city and a global hub. Islam is the official religion; Arabic is the official language, and English is the most spoken language. The UAE has the world’s seventh-largest oil and natural gas reserves. Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan led its development and served as its first president.

paragraphs.context: The Yangtze is the longest river in Eurasia and the third-longest in the world. It originates at Jari Hill in the Tanggula Mountains of the Tibetan Plateau and flows 6,374 km to the East China Sea. It is the fifth-largest river by discharge volume and its drainage basin covers one-fifth of China's land area, supporting nearly one-third of its population. Historically, the Yangtze has been vital to China’s water supply, agriculture, transportation, and industry. The Yangtze Delta contributes around 20% of China's GDP, and the Three Gorges Dam is the world’s largest hydroelectric power station.

answers.text: the world’s largest hydroelectric power station

paragraphs.context: The Asian elephant is the only living species of Elephas and is the largest land animal in Asia. It features a long trunk, large ears, and depigmented grey skin. Males grow large tusks and can weigh up to 4 tons, while females weigh around 2.7 tons. Asian elephants are highly intelligent, with a large neocortex and the ability to demonstrate grief, learning, and social behavior. Three subspecies are recognized: E. m. maximus, E. m. indicus, and E. m. sumatranus. The species is distributed from India and Nepal to Southeast Asia and Sumatra and prefers grasslands, evergreen forests, and dry habitats.

paragraphs.context: The Four Asian Tigers—Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea, and Taiwan—experienced rapid industrial growth between the 1950s and 1990s, exceeding 7% annual economic growth. They transitioned into high-income economies by the 21st century, each specializing in competitive industries. Hong Kong and Singapore are global financial centers, while South Korea and Taiwan lead in electronics manufacturing. These nations have been regarded as models for developing economies. A 1993 World Bank report, The East Asian Miracle, credited their success to export-led growth and neoliberal reforms.

paragraphs.context: The Great Wall of China is a series of fortifications constructed across northern China as defense against nomadic tribes. The earliest walls were built in the 7th century BC and later unified during the Qin dynasty. The most famous sections were built by the Ming dynasty from 1368 to 1644. The wall system included watchtowers, barracks, garrisons, and signal towers for smoke and fire communication. Besides defense, the Wall regulated trade, migration, and customs along the Silk Road. It became a multifunctional structure used for both protection and economic control.

qas.question: Which Chinese dynasty built the best-known sections of the Great Wall?
What communication methods were used along the Great Wall?

answers.text: signal towers for smoke and fire

qas.question: Apart from defense, what other functions did the Great Wall serve?
